post_text: 9th-grade students in the Project NEXT program at Forest Hills Northern High School finished their zoo project. The students were tasked with the main question: How can we build empathy for endangered species in 2019? After students returned from a field trip to John Ball Zoo, they launched a three-phase project spearheaded by biology with English and world history integration. Students conducted ethograms and independent research on an endangered species. They created a fashion show to display their animals' adaptations, and designed and built animal enrichment activities. They created formal presentations about their species and delivered presentations to peers and adults. Lastly, they spent time reflecting on the project and using "circles" to share their reflections.

post_text: We can't wait to start this school year already connected with a new sister school in Beijing. Our Mandarin Chinese immersion program created a new relationship between Beijing Luhe and FHPS. The purpose of this partnership is for Beijing Luhe and FHPS to develop a comprehensive cooperative link to promote cultural communications for teachers and students from Beijing Luhe and FHPS. The goal is to help Beijing Luhe carry out curriculum reform, help Luhe students improve their English, provide them with more opportunities for communication between American students and teachers, and help them achieve a better understanding of United States culture. It will also help students in the FHPS Chinese immersion program improve their Chinese language skills, gain a better awareness and understanding of Chinese culture, and provide teachers and students with opportunities for short-term and long-term cultural exchange. The FHPS Chinese immersion program begins at Meadow Brook Elementary, then Northern Trails 5/6, Northern Hills Middle School, and Northern High School.

post_text: Over the summer, a group of Forest Hills families, staff, and students in the Mandarin Chinese immersion program visited Beijing. While there, they connected with a new sister school, called Luhe. Yuqi Zhao, Luke Florek, Kimberly Wang (NHMS teachers) had a fabulous visit to the Luhe school. Yuqi said, "Parents and students were shocked by the traditional Chinese folk music performance presented by Luhe elementary students. Chinese immersion students also had a marvelous chance to have a Chinese reading class with their Luhe buddies. They read Chinese books together and completed a reading report together. In addition, parents and students had a wonderful time experiencing Chinese painting, Chinese calligraphy, and stamp art together. Last but not least, the Luhe International Academy campus tour left a very deep impression. We look forward to continuing a partnership with Principal Sun from the elementary school and Principal Kong from the high school and thank them for preparing the visit and spending the day with us."
